You can also shut off connection pooling altogether by setting the size of the pool to `0`.

Looking at http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/gone-away.html, there are many reasons this may be happening. Some of the reasons are possibly concerning : 
- You can also encounter this error with applications that fork child processes, all of which try to use the same connection to the MySQL server. This can be avoided by using a separate connection for each child process.
- You can also get these errors if you send a query to the server that is incorrect or too large.
- You tried to run a query after closing the connection to the server. This indicates a logic error in the application that should be corrected.

I don't run MySQL. It would go good to isolate what is going on here for those running on MySQL. @krisskross any further details?

We're not doing anything with the database, it's all airflow. We have other Java applications that pool connections to the same MySQL installation without problems, so this doesn't feel like a configuration issue with MySQL.

I can confirm that I still see this issue (or a similar one) as of master from 16 days ago (forgot to write down the git hash).

In my case it appears to be related to backfilling when there is a task that uses a pool.  My main scheduler is a LocalExecutor and if it is running while I'm backfilling a particular DAG, I'll see the pool oversubscribed. I can work around the problem with this sequence of steps:
- Shut down scheduler
- Use airflow backfill to queue up all the tasks (these tasks share a pool)
- Kill the backfill (which is now waiting for the jobs to complete)
- Start the main scheduler again and watch it start running the queued jobs
Actually, spoke too soon.  I'm seeing it still exceeding the pool limit.  It's running 8 jobs in a pool with a size of 6.

One way to handle this is to do nightlies/hourlies on a fixed schedule, rather than on every commit. Most larger OS projects have something similar to this for integration tests like this. I'm not sure if Travis supports anything like this. I did find:

Cool ! It takes about 30-35mim : https://travis-ci.org/airbnb/airflow/builds/115027370

You could make the `travis.yml` to only run the normal unit tests by default, and use [nightli.es](https://nightli.es/) to override that default `travis.yml` to also run these dag tests on nightly builds.

Travis has that feature to override the default config through its [triggering API](https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/triggering-builds), but I'm not sure if [nightli.es](https://nightli.es/) integrated it yet though.

+1 Took a cursory read of this. My reading is basically, limit `airflow run` to one connection so it doesn't beat up the MySQL db. Is that understanding correct?

Ok I took the time to read this. `BaseJob.run` is not meant to be overridden, `_execute` is, and the way you did it leads to copy pasta duplication, which is bad because the same logic needs to be maintained in different places.

It think that line 887 to 889 are (almost) the only lines of code that need to be added to  `_execute` after the while loop.

Actually what it does is limit it to the connections in use, that haven't been explicitely closed. Otherwise sqlalchemy keeps connections alive in the pool even when `session.close()` is called. Since `airflow run` closes the connections between heartbeats (typically every 30-60 seconds), this means a lot less active connections on the DB.

The scheduler will have its pool, the web server(s) too, and each one of the potentially thousands of tasks will just have short connections "flashes".

As I mentioned in https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/1085
If the concurrency is implemented by checking how many running task instances in database, which means it's possible all tasks can start running at the same time because when they query the database, they all get a count of 0.

And I'm wondering how the executor's state can get out of sync? By multiple schedulers?.

Maybe a better solution is using curator/zookeeper's semaphore to solve this problem(each of the task get a resource from the semaphore).

In summary, simply counting the number of running tasks can lead to concurrency issues when multiple task_instance is checking the database at the same time. We need to solve it using other mechanism

What you're describing sounds a lot like Airflow's BranchPythonOperator, possibly combined with sensors such as ExternalTaskSensor or the SubDagOperator.  

Your current system sounds like typical imperative programming: "do X, then if true do Y" while Airflow is closer to a declarative programming environment "Y depends on result being true, result depends on X".  They can do the same things, but some rethinking is necessary to switch between them.

@mistercrunch Do you have an example? Are you proposing that we alter this manually? In this case, we cannot run both backfill and current runs in unison?

Something like setting `IS_BACKFILL=True` at the top of the dag file and then using `if IS_BACKFILL:...` in the task logic.  Yes, you can't run scheduled and back filled tasks at the same time so the other option is separate dags.
Since the backfill is orchestrated locally, you just alter that variable before running the command.

This addresses https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/1148
I think the expected behavior here is that when a task starts, the xcom is cleared. That will take care of more cases than `airflow clear`.

For any operator that returns a value, that value is available via xcom.

It's important to consider how much data can be returned by an operator, because storing that in the xcom table can be expensive. If you extend the hive operator to return a single value (e.g. like a count query), then that return value will be automatically stored in xcom for you to use. You will then need to read that value in a PythonOperator, BranchPythonOperator, or ShortCircuitOperator, which can do custom logic around emailing and inserting into a DB. I don't think we have a mechanism to pass params to more generic operators from other operators.

I think it should be slightly different. I think operators should push handles to the values to xcom. Those handles could point to something at hdfs, s3, whatever. A bit like the output functions of luigi tasks. This resolves the issue of large datasets and really allow you to work from the data's perspective instead of being task centric.

@dgies Not entirely: if a handler as a generic interface being it iterable or not it does not really matter if it is a "select count(*)" or a handle to a set of files.  So ideally current operators would be adjusted indeed.

@bolkedebruin The problem is if you're implementing this enhancement to HiveOperator, how do you know whether to return a numeric count, or a handle to the HDFS location containing the count?  If you're implementing an operator that uses this result, how do you know what to expect?  A general HiveOperator will have to return an array of result handles to be usable for all possible queries.  Making it _sometimes_ return a single scalar will lead to messy code.

To address a question asked by @thibault-ketterer, this issue differs from https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/262

`Only_run_latest` will be used for a job like a `daily db snapshot` job. Typically, this type of job needs to run once a day. If it doesn't run for 3 days because the DAG was paused, when the DAG is unpaused, the job should not run 3 times. It should only run for the latest time interval. 

What I propose in https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/262 is to mark entries manually as "skipped or do not run" so that the scheduler or backfill job does not attempt them. This could be because we know there is a data problem in the time range.

I'm starting to look into an implementation. It seems that this functionality could be implemented by skipping DAG Runs that are not the latest. Unfortunately, the current handling of "Skipped" is such that it is not compatible with `depends_on_past=True`. So, if we skipped a bunch of DAG Runs and if the DAG specified `depends_on_past=True`, the latest would never be queued. It seems that we first need the system to support `depends_on_past=True` for `skipped` tasks. 

This is a major roadmap item and is tracked in https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/1155
This depends on https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/1155
This will be tracked in https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/1155 so closing this!

I have the same problem.
After some debug, I found these

```
try:
    from airflow.executors.celery_executor import CeleryExecutor
except:
    pass
```

 in 'airflow/executors/**init**.py'

Add a raise instead of pass, error messages give a clue as 

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/data/home/samson/.local/bin/airflow", line 4, in <module>
    from airflow import configuration
  File "/data/home/samson/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/airflow/__init__.py", line 16, in <module>
    from airflow.models import DAG
  File "/data/home/samson/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/airflow/models.py", line 39, in <module>
    from airflow.executors import DEFAULT_EXECUTOR, LocalExecutor
  File "/data/home/samson/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/airflow/executors/__init__.py", line 9, in <module>
    from airflow.executors.celery_executor import CeleryExecutor
  File "/data/home/samson/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/airflow/executors/celery_executor.py", line 6, in <module>
    from celery import Celery
ImportError: No module named celery
```

So just `pip install celery`can fix it.

For my case:
Some of tasks run as hourly and some tasks only run as daily in one DAG. The reason of set depends_on_past to True BCS the today's DAGRUN depend on yesterday result.
